title: China provides China-based training for Cape Verde police in 2016 (linked to #57043)
description: On March 2, 2016, China and the Cape Verde Police Department met and exchanged opinions on implementing the training for police officers of Cape Verde. The Deputy Chief of Cape Verde Police Department agreed to lead a team of senior police officers to take relevant seminars in China.  In 2017, China trained more Cape Verdean police officers, which is recorded in project #57043. The capacity of this training seminar is unknown. The status of this project is also unclear.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China provides China-based training for Cape Verde police in 2016 (linked to #57043)

# Description
On March 2, 2016, China and the Cape Verde Police Department met and exchanged opinions on implementing the training for police officers of Cape Verde. The Deputy Chief of Cape Verde Police Department agreed to lead a team of senior police officers to take relevant seminars in China.  In 2017, China trained more Cape Verdean police officers, which is recorded in project #57043. The capacity of this training seminar is unknown. The status of this project is also unclear.
justification: Project focuses on police training and capacity building, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Training for police officers, capacity building focus, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 599.2 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of Vaico Irrigation Project (Linked to Project ID#39178, #62162)
description: On October 13, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 599,253,500 government concessional loan (GCL) for Phase 2 of the Vaico Irrigation Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL were as follows: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate. On the same day, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 229,384,200 interest-free loan agreement for Phase 2 of the Vaico Irrigation Project (captured in Project ID#62162). The borrowing terms of the loan from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) were as follows: 20-year maturity, 10-year grace period, and 0% interest rate. According to the Government of Cambodia’s ODA Database, China Eximbank made two loan disbursements between 2020 and 2021 (an RMB 49,210,533 loan disbursement in 2020, and an RMB 16,403,536 loan disbursement in 2021) and MOFCOM made two loan disbursements between 2020 and 2021 (an RMB 42,543,117 loan disbursement in 2020, and an RMB 14,181,11 loan disbursement in 2021).   The purpose of this project is to improve the provision of irrigated water to Kampong Cham and Prey Veng provinces. The purpose of the project’s second phase is to improve the provision of irrigated water to Kampong Cham and Prey Veng provinces. Phase 2 includes two parts. Part I was supported by the GCL and it involved the construction of irrigation canal infrastructure in Svay Rieng and Prey Veng provinces — including 2 main canals, a 23.5 km long canal, and a reservoir. Upon completion, Part I was expected to irrigate over 10,000 ha of rice paddies. Part II was supported by the ETCA (interest-free loan). It was initially designed to support Kampong Cham, Prey Veng, and Svay Rieng provinces, but later rescoped to only cover Prey Veng and Svay Rieng provinces. The project’s first and second phases were together expected to provide irrigation to an estimated 250,00014-300,000 hectares of farmland, thereby providing a stable irrigation source for farmers to increase their yields and improve their resiliency in the face of climate change and reduce the prevalence of hunger and poverty in the region.   Guangdong Foreign Construction Co., Ltd. (GDFC) was the EPC contractor responsible for Phase 2 implementation. Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Co., Ltd. (GWCSC) was responsible for project supervision and management. This project commenced on November 1, 2016 and it was originally expected to reach completion in December 2019. On January 23, 2021, Rasmei Kampuchea Daily Newspaper reported that Phase 2 was nearly complete, with all canals completed in Prey Veng province and ongoing construction activities in Svay Rieng province. Multiple sources indicated that Phase 2 is completion. However, its precise date of completion is unknown. Cambodia’s Ministry of Water Resources and Meteorology (MoWRaM) has noted that once the construction company completed work on the project, it would be handed over to MoWRaM for management.
staff_comments: 1. The China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 2 is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020. 2. China Eximbank also provided a loan for Phase 1 of the Vaico Irrigation Project (captured in Project ID#39178)
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 599.2 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of Vaico Irrigation Project (Linked to Project ID#39178, #62162)

# Description
On October 13, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 599,253,500 government concessional loan (GCL) for Phase 2 of the Vaico Irrigation Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL were as follows: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate. On the same day, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 229,384,200 interest-free loan agreement for Phase 2 of the Vaico Irrigation Project (captured in Project ID#62162). The borrowing terms of the loan from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) were as follows: 20-year maturity, 10-year grace period, and 0% interest rate. According to the Government of Cambodia’s ODA Database, China Eximbank made two loan disbursements between 2020 and 2021 (an RMB 49,210,533 loan disbursement in 2020, and an RMB 16,403,536 loan disbursement in 2021) and MOFCOM made two loan disbursements between 2020 and 2021 (an RMB 42,543,117 loan disbursement in 2020, and an RMB 14,181,11 loan disbursement in 2021).   The purpose of this project is to improve the provision of irrigated water to Kampong Cham and Prey Veng provinces. The purpose of the project’s second phase is to improve the provision of irrigated water to Kampong Cham and Prey Veng provinces. Phase 2 includes two parts. Part I was supported by the GCL and it involved the construction of irrigation canal infrastructure in Svay Rieng and Prey Veng provinces — including 2 main canals, a 23.5 km long canal, and a reservoir. Upon completion, Part I was expected to irrigate over 10,000 ha of rice paddies. Part II was supported by the ETCA (interest-free loan). It was initially designed to support Kampong Cham, Prey Veng, and Svay Rieng provinces, but later rescoped to only cover Prey Veng and Svay Rieng provinces. The project’s first and second phases were together expected to provide irrigation to an estimated 250,00014-300,000 hectares of farmland, thereby providing a stable irrigation source for farmers to increase their yields and improve their resiliency in the face of climate change and reduce the prevalence of hunger and poverty in the region.   Guangdong Foreign Construction Co., Ltd. (GDFC) was the EPC contractor responsible for Phase 2 implementation. Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Co., Ltd. (GWCSC) was responsible for project supervision and management. This project commenced on November 1, 2016 and it was originally expected to reach completion in December 2019. On January 23, 2021, Rasmei Kampuchea Daily Newspaper reported that Phase 2 was nearly complete, with all canals completed in Prey Veng province and ongoing construction activities in Svay Rieng province. Multiple sources indicated that Phase 2 is completion. However, its precise date of completion is unknown. Cambodia’s Ministry of Water Resources and Meteorology (MoWRaM) has noted that once the construction company completed work on the project, it would be handed over to MoWRaM for management.
justification: Project focuses on irrigation infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of irrigation canals and reservoir for agricultural purposes, no direct energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China donates 138 laptop computers to Cambodian youth union
description: On March 28th, 2016, the Chinese Embassy to Cambodia on Monday handed over 138 sets of laptop computers worth 170,000 U.S. dollars to the Union of Youth Federations of Cambodia (UYFC). Many said the laptop computers would be distributed equally to UYFC branches in all 25 cities and provinces.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China donates 138 laptop computers to Cambodian youth union

# Description
On March 28th, 2016, the Chinese Embassy to Cambodia on Monday handed over 138 sets of laptop computers worth 170,000 U.S. dollars to the Union of Youth Federations of Cambodia (UYFC). Many said the laptop computers would be distributed equally to UYFC branches in all 25 cities and provinces.
justification: Project involves donation of computer equipment for social development purposes with no direct energy or environmental impact
evidence: Donation of 138 laptop computers to youth organization, no energy or infrastructure components

title: China donates office equipment to Cambodia
description: The Chinese government donated office equipment worth 800,000 yuan (121,553 U.S. dollars) to the Cambodian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation. This donation is one of a number of office equipment donations made by the Chinese government over the 2010-2017 period.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates office equipment to Cambodia

# Description
The Chinese government donated office equipment worth 800,000 yuan (121,553 U.S. dollars) to the Cambodian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation. This donation is one of a number of office equipment donations made by the Chinese government over the 2010-2017 period.
justification: Project involves donation of office equipment with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Office equipment donation to government ministry, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 252 million government concessional loan for National Road No. 51 (NR 51) Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#61176)
description: On October 13, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance signed an RMB 252,045,640 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the National Road No. 51 (NR 51) Construction Project (as captured in this project). The GCL carried the following terms: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate.  On the same day, the Chinese Government institution issued a second loan to the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance — through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) — worth RMB 97,135,600 for the same project (captured in linked Project ID#61176). It carried a 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and was interest-free.  The proceeds from these two loans were used to finance an EPC contract with China Road & Bridge Corporation (CRBC). The purpose of the project was to construct a 37.96 km segment of National Road No. 51 (NR 51) that connects National Road No. 5 (NR 5) and National Road No. 4 (NR 4) and leads directly to Sihanoukville Port. The 12-meter wide road segment is located in the central-southern part of Cambodia at the boundary of Kampong Speu Province and Kandal Province.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 14, 2017 and the project was expected to reach completion on December 31, 2019. It was ultimately completed on August 12, 2020.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the National Road No. 51 (NR 51) Expansion Project. NR 51 is also known as the Udong-Thnal Totoeng Road. The Chinese project title is 51号国家公路 or 柬埔寨51号公路项目. The Khmer project title is ផ្លូវជាតិលេខ៥១.2. The Government of Cambodia’s aid and debt information management system, which is maintained on behalf of all ministries and agencies of the Royal Government of Cambodia by the Cambodian Rehabilitation and Development Board (CRDB) of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC) records the interest rate as 2%; however, this appears to be a typographical error, as given that the RMB 97,135,600 loan (captured in linked ProjectID#61176) was funded through an ETCA, it was likely an interest-free loan, which is also confirmed in several sources (See: 31 documents to be signed between Cambodia and China (Oct 2016)).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 252 million government concessional loan for National Road No. 51 (NR 51) Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#61176)

# Description
On October 13, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance signed an RMB 252,045,640 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the National Road No. 51 (NR 51) Construction Project (as captured in this project). The GCL carried the following terms: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate.  On the same day, the Chinese Government institution issued a second loan to the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance — through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) — worth RMB 97,135,600 for the same project (captured in linked Project ID#61176). It carried a 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and was interest-free.  The proceeds from these two loans were used to finance an EPC contract with China Road & Bridge Corporation (CRBC). The purpose of the project was to construct a 37.96 km segment of National Road No. 51 (NR 51) that connects National Road No. 5 (NR 5) and National Road No. 4 (NR 4) and leads directly to Sihanoukville Port. The 12-meter wide road segment is located in the central-southern part of Cambodia at the boundary of Kampong Speu Province and Kandal Province.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 14, 2017 and the project was expected to reach completion on December 31, 2019. It was ultimately completed on August 12, 2020.
justification: Road construction project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of 37.96 km road segment connecting national roads, general transportation infrastructure

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 388 million government concessional loan for the Second Ring Road (West Section) of Phnom Penh Project
description: On October 13, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 388,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Second Ring Road (West Section) of Phnom Penh Project. The GCL carried the following terms: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG).  The purpose of the project was to construct a 16.67 km ring road southwest of the city of Phnom Penh. The road was designed to run across two lanes from Russian Federation Blvd to National Road No. 2 and across the districts of Dangkor, Sen Sok and Meanchey heading south to Takmao town.  SCG was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Construction started on March 6, 2017. The project had achieved a 50% completion rate as of November 2017.  It was ultimately completed on April 12, 2018.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the West Second Ring Road of Phnom Penh Project and the West Section of The Second Ring Road of Phnom Penh Project. The Chinese project title is 柬埔寨金边市第二环线（西段）项目. The Khmer project title is ផ្លូវក្រវ៉ាត់ក្រុងខ្សែទី២.2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 388 million government concessional loan for the Second Ring Road (West Section) of Phnom Penh Project

# Description
On October 13, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 388,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Second Ring Road (West Section) of Phnom Penh Project. The GCL carried the following terms: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG).  The purpose of the project was to construct a 16.67 km ring road southwest of the city of Phnom Penh. The road was designed to run across two lanes from Russian Federation Blvd to National Road No. 2 and across the districts of Dangkor, Sen Sok and Meanchey heading south to Takmao town.  SCG was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Construction started on March 6, 2017. The project had achieved a 50% completion rate as of November 2017.  It was ultimately completed on April 12, 2018.
justification: Project is focused on road construction without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 16.67 km ring road construction, general transportation infrastructure

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 57 million grant for Enhancement of Public Transportation Project
description: On December 14, 2016, the Chinese Government granted RMB 57 million for the Enhancement of Public Transportation Project. Under this project, China Yutong Company provided 100 public transport vehicles to the city of Phnom Penh.  The project started began on December 16, 2016 ("Project/Program Information and Implementation Arrangments", "中国与柬埔寨签署无偿援助经济技术合作协定"). The handover ceremony was held on July 13, 2017 ("檀勍生临时代办出席援柬100辆公交车辆项目交接仪式"). These buses will be used to open new bus routes, improve transportation, and reduce congestion, traffic accidents, and environmental pollution in Phnom Penh.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 57 million grant for Enhancement of Public Transportation Project

# Description
On December 14, 2016, the Chinese Government granted RMB 57 million for the Enhancement of Public Transportation Project. Under this project, China Yutong Company provided 100 public transport vehicles to the city of Phnom Penh.  The project started began on December 16, 2016 ("Project/Program Information and Implementation Arrangments", "中国与柬埔寨签署无偿援助经济技术合作协定"). The handover ceremony was held on July 13, 2017 ("檀勍生临时代办出席援柬100辆公交车辆项目交接仪式"). These buses will be used to open new bus routes, improve transportation, and reduce congestion, traffic accidents, and environmental pollution in Phnom Penh.
justification: Project focuses on public transportation improvement without clear energy transition or environmental impact focus
evidence: Provision of 100 public transport vehicles, focus on reducing congestion and traffic accidents

title: Chinese Government provides $17 million concessional loan for Cambodia-China Sen Sok Overpass Bridge Project
description: In 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia signed a $17 million concessional loan agreement for the Cambodia-China Sen Sok Overpass Bridge Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The proceeds were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG).  This project involved the construction of a 16.5-meter-wide and 942-meter-long overpass (the Cambodia-China Sen Sok Overpass Bridge) at the intersection of Russian Federation Boulevard and Hanoi Street in Sen Sok district within the city of  Phnom Penh. The ultimate purpose of the project was to ease the transport of goods and travel of people in Phnom Penh, especially those who travel to and from Phnom Penh International Airport.  SCG was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Co., Ltd. was responsible for project supervision. The project officially commenced on June 5, 2016, and it was completed on July 2, 2018.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Psar Dei Hoy Flyover Project or the Phsar Dey Hoy Flyover Project. The Chinese project title is 金边塞索柬中友谊立交桥. 2. Given that this project was financed with a 'concessional loan', China Eximbank is the most likely lender (funding agency). However, this issue requires further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government provides $17 million concessional loan for Cambodia-China Sen Sok Overpass Bridge Project

# Description
In 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia signed a $17 million concessional loan agreement for the Cambodia-China Sen Sok Overpass Bridge Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The proceeds were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG).  This project involved the construction of a 16.5-meter-wide and 942-meter-long overpass (the Cambodia-China Sen Sok Overpass Bridge) at the intersection of Russian Federation Boulevard and Hanoi Street in Sen Sok district within the city of  Phnom Penh. The ultimate purpose of the project was to ease the transport of goods and travel of people in Phnom Penh, especially those who travel to and from Phnom Penh International Airport.  SCG was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. Guangzhou Wanan Construction Supervision Co., Ltd. was responsible for project supervision. The project officially commenced on June 5, 2016, and it was completed on July 2, 2018.
justification: Project is a transportation infrastructure project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of overpass bridge for transportation purposes, no mention of energy or environmental components

On January 23, 2021, Rasmei Kampuchea Daily Newspaper reported that Phase 2 was nearly complete, with all canals completed in Prey Veng province and ongoing construction activities in Svay Rieng province. Multiple sources indicated that Phase 2 is completion. However, its precise date of completion is unknown. Cambodia’s Ministry of Water Resources and Meteorology (MoWRaM) has noted that once the construction company completed work on the project, it would be handed over to MoWRaM for management.
justification: Project focuses on irrigation infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of irrigation canals and reservoir, aimed at improving agricultural water supply and resilience
